title: Presidential Approval Ratings
question_text:
Two polling organizations, Harris and Gallup, report weekly on the President’s approval rating, which is expressed as a proportion of Americans who approve of the job the President is doing.
In one particular week, each organization asks $100$ randomly selected people this question. Their results are as follows:
Harris Poll: $0.57$ Gallup Poll: $0.6$
What are the mean and standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the difference of these organizations’ results?
solution:
The mean of the differences will be the difference in the two proportions, which is $0.6-0.57 = 0.03$.

The standard deviation is a bit more complicated, and it requires the use of the formula:

$$\sqrt{\dfrac{\hat{p_1}(1- \hat{p_1})}{n_1} + \dfrac{\hat{p_2}(1- \hat{p_2})}{n_2}}$$

Substitute $100$ for both ${ n }_{ 1 }$ and ${ n }_{ 2 }$ as these are the sample sizes. $\hat{p_1}= 0.6$, and $\hat{p_2}= 0.57$.

This yields $ \sigma = 0.06965$, which rounds to $0.07$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
